I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  Central  Asia  Regional  Economic  Cooperation  (CAREC)  Program1 emphasizes 
pragmatism and results. The long-term vision is of “Good Neighbors, Good Partners, and Good 
Prospects.” The 5th Ministerial Conference, held 18–20 October 2006 in Urumqi, the People’s 
Republic of China (PRC), adopted the Urumqi Declaration and endorsed the comprehensive 
action  plan  (CAP).  The  declaration  reaffirms  each  country’s  commitment  to  development 
through cooperation leading to accelerated economic growth and poverty reduction, and to be 
consistent with the CAP in a manner that avoids duplication and maximizes the efficient use of 
resources. The CAP2 provides strategic direction to the CAREC Program for the medium to long 
term, setting out the goals, objectives, and expected outputs and outcomes in a results-based 
format. The CAP knowledge and capacity building pillar proposes the formation of the CAREC 
Institute to coordinate research, training and dialogue activities for the CAREC Program. The 
mission of the CAREC Institute, a virtual institute supported by the CAREC Secretariat, is to 
enhance the quality of regional cooperation by generating world-class knowledge resources to 
support regional infrastructure networks in the priority areas of transportation, trade, and energy, 
which will lead to greater capacities for regional cooperation and accelerated economic growth 
in Central Asia. The institute’s prospectus was endorsed at the 6th Ministerial Conference, held 
2–3 November 2007, in Dushanbe, Tajikistan.  
 
2.  Considerable capacity-building and initial research activities have been undertaken by 
the CAREC Program.3 The CAREC Institute provides the foundations for a more coordinated 
approach to the design and implementation of learning activities, and the harnessing of local 
knowledge and research capabilities with the support of the six CAREC participating multilateral 
institutions. The Greater Mekong Subregion Phnom Penh Plan for development management 
has been studied and the institute will build on the lessons learned. The design and monitoring 
framework is shown in Appendix 1.4 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  The  CAREC  participating  countries  face  a  large  number  of  interrelated  issues  and 
constraints based in part on their history and their location in Asia, a situation that provides both 
opportunities  and  challenges.  To  succeed  in  this  environment,  the  CAREC  participating 
countries are reorienting their economies, consolidating their relationships with trading partners, 
and improving the legal and regulatory frameworks and systems to support private sector 
investment. Regional cooperation and integration provide a framework for economic dialogue 
between  the  countries,  and  an  opportunity  to  allocate  scarce  resources,  including  human 
capacity, to the sectors and areas where most value can be created. CAREC participating 
countries  face  many  capacity  challenges.  A  central  feature  of  the  CAREC  Program  is  to 
                                                 
1  Eight  countries  participate  in  the  CAREC  Program:  Afghanistan,  Azerbaijan,  People’s  Republic  of  China, 
Kazakhstan, Kyrgyz Republic, Mongolia, Tajikistan, and Uzbekistan. They are joined by six multilateral institutions: 
ADB, European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, International Monetary Fund, Islamic Development 
Bank, United Nations Development Programme, and World Bank. 
2  The CAP has four action pillars to achieve development through cooperation and aims to strengthen other 
principles such as ownership by the CAREC participating countries and partnership with the business community 
and regional organizations. The action pillars are (i) knowledge and capacity building; (ii) regional infrastructure 
networks; (iii) trade, investment, and business development; and (iv) regional public goods.

2   
upgrade the skills and knowledge of public sector officials involved in regional cooperation work. 
The  capacity  challenges  can  be  classified  into  two  broad  categories:  (i)  human  resource 
challenges, and (ii) institutional challenges. The human resource challenges are the shortage of 
skilled labor needed to complete each country's transition to a market economy and to promote 
regional cooperation. These challenges relate to the change in mind-set needed to support a 
more client-oriented approach to public service delivery. The institutional capacity challenges 
relate to the need for well-equipped administrative and bureaucratic structures to undertake, 
consolidate, and sustain reforms. 
 
4.  There  is  considerable  scope  for  sharing  curriculum  and  training  programs  across 
countries, and bringing in expertise from outside of the region. The CAREC Program’s capacity-
building activities have demonstrated some success in sharing technologies from the PRC 
public service with other CAREC participating countries. Stronger linkages need to be formed 
among the research and training institutions within the region. Training and research networks 
exist in CAREC participating countries, and it is proposed that this TA be used to strengthen 
such networks to focus on regional cooperation in the priority sectors of transport, energy, and 
trade. Proposed activities will improve the enabling environment for private sector investment 
and industrial development, and address issues surrounding regional public goods. 
  
5.  In mid-2007, the CAREC Secretariat assessed participating countries' training needs to 
better understand requirements in relation to regional cooperation and to identify specific course 
offerings  as  part  of  a  larger  capacity  development  program.  To  establish  the  demand  for 
courses, a two-step process was designed, including (i) a survey questionnaire, and (ii) in-
country workshops held for over 100 potential participants for building capacity in five CAREC 
participating countries. The training assessment established a positive demand for training 
among  senior  and  mid-level  officials.  Senior  officials  were  unanimous  in  their  request  for 
courses  that  would  provide  macrolevel  perspective,  strategic  vision  and  wide-ranging 
knowledge. Demand is strong for courses in leadership, negotiations for regional agreements, 
public policy, and public sector reform. Mid-level officials highlighted the need for specialized 
skills and technical knowledge in the discharge of their responsibilities. 
 
6.    Capacity-building initiatives to strengthen participants’ knowledge and skills for regional 
cooperation activities are needed. The enhanced knowledge and skills will in turn lead to more 
effective development policies and a greater number of regional projects and initiatives from the 
CAREC countries. Knowledge-sharing activities will not be limited to government officials, but 
will also cover the private sector, such as business associations, chambers of commerce, and 
organizations of freight forwarders. Research activities will generate expert information and 
analysis that other researchers, government officials, and policy makers can use in planning 
and  implementing  regional  activities.  Shared  knowledge  from  joint  research,  training,  and 
dialogue channels is expected to result in a greater convergence of participating countries’ 
economic development policies in areas covered by regional cooperation and will be based on 
best practice. These activities should also contribute to the emergence or strengthening of 
“policy  communities”  of  researchers,  academic  institutions,  policy  makers,  and  other 
stakeholders  to  facilitate  dialogue and  enhance  the impact  of  applied  research and  policy 
studies in CAREC’s priority areas. 
 
7.  The  CAREC  Institute  has  been  established  as  a  virtual  institute  supported  by  the 
CAREC Secretariat and the contributing multilateral institution partners. As such, the institute

3
will not have any permanent location, infrastructure, or staff.5  In this regard, the sustainability of 
the institute is a key issue over the longer term. In the short term, cofinancing from ADB and 
development partners will be able to sufficiently support the institute’s undertakings. Over the 
longer term and with further economic development of the CAREC participating countries, it is 
expected that the countries themselves would be able to cover an increasing share of the 
CAREC Institute costs.  
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The impact of the technical assistance (TA) is closer regional cooperation among the 
CAREC participating countries. The outcome is the effective functioning of the CAREC Institute 
in delivering training, research, and dialogue activities. The enhanced knowledge and skills of 
CAREC  government  officials  and  other  stakeholders  will,  in  turn,  lead  to  more  rapid 
identification and development of regional projects in CAREC priority areas, a greater number of 
regional proposals and activities initiated by CAREC countries, and more effective regional 
cooperation. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  The CAREC Institute’s main outputs are (i) a capacity building training program to 
improve knowledge and skills of government officials in areas related to regional cooperation; (ii) 
an applied research program, to generate new knowledge, innovation, and recommendations 
that will support more effective regional cooperation; and (iii) an outreach program, to extend 
the impact of the institute’s training and research more broadly. Partnerships and collaboration 
with institutes, experts, and researchers from the CAREC countries will be a central element of 
the institute's work in each of these areas. The institute will regularly report on its activities to 
senior  officials’  meetings  and  will  prepare  a  progress  report  on  its  activities  and  resource 
utilization to be submitted annually to the ministerial conference. This TA will be sufficiently 
flexible to accommodate the evolving nature of the CAREC Program.  
 
10.  The institute's training program will operate with a number of partners, including (i) other 
institutes or capacity-building networks, (ii) advanced training institutions, (iii) beneficiary training 
institutions, and (iv) multilateral institutions. The program will address the needs identified in the 
training needs assessment at two levels. An executive leadership development program (ELDP) 
will be developed and offered in collaboration with a leading international university or business 
school to meet the identified needs of senior officials for courses in leadership, negotiation for 
regional agreements, public policy and public sector reform. Elements of the leadership course, 
combined with support for the active training programs of the CAREC sector committees for 
transport, trade facilitation, energy, and trade policy, will meet the identified needs of mid-level 
officials for specialized skills and technical knowledge. 
 
11.  The institute's research program will also operate with a number of partners, including (i) 
other research networks, (ii) research institutions in CAREC countries, (iii) CAREC's multilateral 
institution  partners,  (iv)  leading  research  institutions  outside  CAREC  countries,  and  (v) 
renowned individual experts. Research will support the development of a sound knowledge 
base in the CAREC priority areas. This will include projects to (i) analyze the impact of regional

cooperation, (ii) explore opportunities for structural transformation of the CAREC participating 
economies, and (iii) examine regional approaches to addressing the challenges of landlocked 
economies and dependence on natural resources in the Central Asian context. In addition to 
larger  research  projects,  a  competitive  research  grants  component  will  be  implemented  to 
promote research on regional cooperation undertaken by experts from CAREC countries.6 In 
addition, a few small grants not exceeding a total of $40,000 in any given year, may also be 
negotiated directly with selected research institutes to build local capacity for policy analysis.   
 
12.  An indicative set of activities for the training and research programs is presented in 
Appendix 2. 
 
13.  The institute's outreach program will enable information generated through the training 
and research programs to be shared with parties in the broader development community, the 
private sector, and other relevant stakeholders in the CAREC process. A key element of the 
outreach program will be the development of an information portal to provide all interested 
parties access to available training materials, research outputs, and information of relevance to 
the work of the CAREC Program that has been developed by CAREC partners and others. In 
addition, the institute will foster dialogue and debate on relevant regional issues through the 
development and sponsorship of publications, conferences, seminars, and other information 
dissemination activities. 
 
14.  During its initial stage, the CAREC Institute will be closely linked with the CAREC 
Secretariat  for  technical  and  administrative  support,  and  to  facilitate  coordination  between 
CAREC priority agendas and the institute’s activities.  
 
15.  A performance review of the institute is planned for 2010. The review will assess the 
institute's achievements, challenges and constraints. It will examine approaches to building on 
areas of success and to identifying practical responses to challenges and constraints that will 
contribute to improved efficiency of and stronger support for the broader work of the CAREC 
Program.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $5.2 million. ADB will finance $4.0 million of this amount 
from its TA special fund and $0.5 million from the Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund 
under the Regional Cooperation and Integration Financing Partnership Facility. ADB will also 
administer the balance of $0.5 million cofinanced from the People’s Republic of China Regional 
Cooperation  and  Poverty  Reduction  Fund.  The  participating  governments  will  provide  the 
remaining $0.2 million, which is the estimated value of logistical support for meetings and staff 
time for activities. The detailed cost estimates are in Appendix 3. Over time, additional support 
in funding or in kind will be sought from the CAREC participating governments and development 
partners to finance an expanded program of training, research, and outreach activities.

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  The TA will be implemented over 39 months from 1 January 2009 to 31 March 2012.7 
ADB will be the Executing Agency, and ADB’s CAREC Unit in the Country Coordination and 
Regional Cooperation Division of the Central and West Asia Department will be responsible for 
overall implementation of TA activities. The CAREC Unit, acting as the Implementing Agency, 
will be responsible for day-to-day implementation activities. The CAREC Unit will maintain close 
coordination with the East Asia Department, particularly the Regional Cooperation, Governance, 
and  Finance  Division.  For  implementing  the  TA,  about  34  person-months  of  international 
consulting services and 138 person-months of national consulting services will be engaged. 
ADB will engage consultants through the quality- and cost-based selection process to develop 
and  implement  the  ELDP.8 ADB  will  also  engage  consultants  on  an  individual  basis  in 
accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to 
time). Resource persons for about 20 assignments will be engaged to support the development 
and delivery of training and capacity-building activities. The terms of reference for consultants 
are in Appendix 4. Equipment budgeted under the TA consists of a limited number of computers 
and office equipment that will be procured in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines 
(2007, as amended from time to time) and left with the CAREC Unit upon completion of the TA. 
 
18.  The outputs of the TA will be disseminated at CAREC senior officials' meetings and 
ministerial  conferences,  and  through  the  CAREC  Institute  portal,  outreach  events,  and 
publications. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION AND DECISION 
19.  The President recommends that the Board approve the provision of technical assistance 
not exceeding the equivalent of $4,500,000 on a grant basis for the Central Asia Regional 
Economic Cooperation Institute, 2009–2012. If the Board approves ADB providing the technical 
assistance, the President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, will approve ADB 
administering the balance of the technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 
to be financed on a grant basis by the People's Republic of China Regional Cooperation and 
Poverty Reduction Fund for the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation Institute, 2009–
2012.
                                                 
7  ADB will obtain a separate no-objection letter from the CAREC participating countries before the TA undertakes 
any activities. 
8  A  leading  university  or  business  school  with  significant  experience  in  customized,  multi-cultural  executive 
education, including delivery of multi-language, multi-country programs, will be engaged to develop and deliver the 
ELDP. Given the limited number of institutions meeting these requirements it is anticipated the shortlist of potential 
providers will number three to four institutions.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The technical assistance will require about 34 person-months of international and 138 
person-months  of  national  consultant  inputs.  Additional  short-term  international  and  national 
consultants may be engaged to assist in assessing (i) knowledge and skills needs, and (ii) local 
research  and  training  institutes  in  Central  Asia  Regional  Economic  Cooperation  (CAREC) 
participating countries. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will engage all consultants according 
to its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). 
A.  International Consultants 
2.  The following international consultants will work under the supervision of ADB staff. 
1.  Advisor (12 person-months)  
3.  Independent individual consultants will be engaged to provide the following services. 
(i)  Advise the CAREC Institute on development of its role, work program, and functions. 
(ii)  Advise on approaches to and development of specific elements of the CAREC 
Institute research program and capacity development program. 
(iii)  Advise on approaches to strengthening engagement of development partners in the 
work of the CAREC Institute and to securing financial contributions. 
(iv)  Act as a resource person at CAREC Program and CAREC Institute activities as 
required. 
(v)  Review and comment on research work and other relevant documents and plans. 
 
2.  Researcher (22 person-months)  
4.  Independent individual consultants will be engaged to provide the following services: 
(i)  Perform analytical studies, particularly in the priority areas of transport, energy, 
trade policy, and trade facilitation. 
(ii)  Undertake desk reviews on specific topics relevant to the CAREC program. 
(iii)  Work  with  and  strengthen  research  institutions  and  researchers  within  CAREC 
participating countries on specific research activities. 
(iv)  Aid networking between researchers within CAREC countries and outside the region 
to facilitate research on specific topics in regional cooperation. 
 
B.  National Consultants 
1.  Program Manager (36 person-months)  
5.  Independent individual consultants will be engaged, and under the supervision of ADB staff 
will manage the day-to-day implementation of the CAREC Institute work program. The program 
manager will provide the following services: 
(i)  Help lead the capacity development program, including the development of the work 
program in research, training, and outreach. 
(ii)  Manage the day-to-day implementation of the capacity development program. 
(iii)  Assist with the engagement and supervision of sector experts. 
(iv)  Identify training courses, and contribute to their design. 
(v)  Analyze the training needs of participating countries.  
(vi)  Assist preparation of training curriculum and materials to ensure programs meet the 
learning and skills development needs of participants. 
(vii)  Manage the logistic element in the delivery of training programs.

2.  Research Officer (36 person-months)  
6.  Independent individual consultants will be engaged and, under the supervision of ADB staff, 
will provide the following services: 
(i)  Assist  in  coordinating,  integrating,  and  monitoring  activities  under  the  regional 
technical assistance. 
(ii)  Assist in supervising, coordinating, and reviewing the work of consultants in relation 
to the research program of the CAREC Institute. 
(iii)  Prepare budgets for research projects and administer contracts. 
(iv)  Organize the translation of training and research materials. 
(v)  Provide administrative inputs to the CAREC small research grants program. 
(vi)  Assist with logistical arrangements for training and outreach events, in coordination 
with regional cooperation coordinators in ADB resident missions. 
(vii)  Prepare background documents as required. 
(viii)  Administratively support research activities of the CAREC Institute as needed. 
(ix)  Participate in missions as required. 
 
3.  Sector Experts (30 person-months) 
7.  Individual independent consultants will be engaged and under the supervision of ADB staff 
will provide the following services: 
(i)  Prepare methodologies for research activities. 
(ii)  Conduct research in their sector of expertise under defined terms of reference in 
support of CAREC Institute research projects. 
(iii)  Assess and analyze research data. 
 
4.  Website and Publication Officer (36 person-months)  
8.  Under the supervision of ADB staff, independent individual consultants will be engaged to 
provide the following services: 
(i)  Assist in developing the concept and design of the CAREC Institute web portal. 
(ii)  Develop information for and ensure regular updating of the website. 
(iii)  Coordinate the preparation of marketing materials, brochures, and publications for 
the CAREC Institute. 
(iv)  Supervise the layout, typesetting, and translation of CAREC publications. 
(v)  Liaise with the ADB Department of External Relations and the Printing Unit for 
clearance and production of CAREC publications. 
(vi)  Assist in preparing presentation materials, reports, and other documents for use in 
high-level meetings and conferences. 
 
C.  International and National Consultants 
1.  International and Local Resource Persons (20 person-assignments)  
9.  Resource persons may be engaged to work closely with responsible ADB staff in preparing 
specific materials and make presentations at workshops and other related training events. These 
resource persons may also be ADB staff.
